Literature Review: Graphene and other two-dimensional (2D) materials have emerged as promising candidates for the development of highly sensitive and specific biosensors due to their unique properties, including high specific surface area (SSA), excellent electrical conductivity, and tunable electronic properties. These materials offer a platform for detecting a wide range of biomolecules, from small ions to large proteins, with unprecedented sensitivity and selectivity. This literature review explores the current state of research on graphene and 2D materials for biomolecule sensing, focusing on their fundamental properties, sensing mechanisms, and challenges in practical applications.
